comment.author: 32162360@N00
comment._content: Good description of the SPRAY in Newcastle in September 1896 (first Australian port-of-call) - trove.nla.gov.au/ndp/del/article/14068752 , and an unloved photo in the CCUN photostream - [http://www.flickr.com/photos/uon/6913803785/]

comment.author: 32162360@N00
comment._content: He moored first at North Harbour for a few days, and a welcoming party towed him into Sydney - trove.nla.gov.au/ndp/del/article/14070535 , including boorish behaviour from crowd on the LADY MANNING. On public view at Manly Pier in October 1896 - trove.nla.gov.au/ndp/del/article/14070913 Shark catching! Melbourne January, 1897 - trove.nla.gov.au/ndp/del/article/14082903 [putting the story together ...]

comment.author: 33147718@N05
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/beachcomberaustralia] It's a great story isn't it? His life reads like a classic boys adventure novel - sharks and all. Did you see he married while in Australia in 1871? (Hence the ladies by the name of 'Walker' who were described as relatives in the first article.) Love that the first article recorded both the boorish behaviour of LADY MANNING's passengers, as well as each round of applause!
comment.authorname: Australian National Maritime Museum on The Commons

comment.author: 32162360@N00
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/anmm_thecommons] I should read his book rather than piece together possibly innaccurate newspaper reports!  Are there more SPRAY photos to come?

comment.author: 33147718@N05
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/beachcomberaustralia] Sadly no :( I couldn't find any further images of Slocum or SPRAY - well at least where they are identified. You can find his book online here, complete with oddly robotic audio!
comment.authorname: Australian National Maritime Museum on The Commons

comment.author: 32162360@N00
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/anmm_thecommons] Thanks! Terrific to be able to read the book online, and link to the relevant pages - arrival at Newcastle and Australian ports p.167 on - www.archive.org/stream/sailingalonearou00sloc#page/166/mo... . The SPRAY was back in Sydney on the way north between 22/4/1897 and 9/5/1987 (p.185) and lost a chain and anchor when rammed by a steamer near Watsons Bay. I wonder if anyone ever found it and donated it to the ANMM !

comment.author: 33147718@N05
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/beachcomberaustralia] Wouldn't that be wonderful!? After a quick search of our database, and then the online databases of other museums, it appears that the chain and anchor are not part of a museum collection... Perhaps still at the bottom of Watsons Bay? I love the description of the young visitor to SPRAY falling into a barrel of water - complete with picture :)
comment.authorname: Australian National Maritime Museum on The Commons

comment.author: 32162360@N00
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/anmm_thecommons] Great blog entry about the SPRAY - recommended! - anmm.wordpress.com/2013/07/05/alone-on-the-wide-wide-sea-...

comment.author: 33147718@N05
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/beachcomberaustralia] Thanks BC! 'Sailing Alone Around the World' - certainly worth a read to sailors & non-sailors alike :) The New Bedford Whaling Museum also kindly agreed to let me use their portrait of Slocum in the blog.
comment.authorname: Australian National Maritime Museum on The Commons
